pros:
Amazing teammates really help balance the highs and lows of this job. Given that it's a 24 hour operation, the people on the team become a second family. The flight benefits and flexibility to trade shifts also make this a great job for someone who wants to see the world, while also having the freedom for other commitments. There is an option to work from home if you're on an overnight shift, which is great! You will truly get a sense of how the airline operates and understand the dynamics of different teams, the in and outs of aviation, customer service and daily operations. 

This is a great stepping stone for growing your career, networking and learning social media best practices. I strongly recommend if you're interested in holding a higher title, you seek mentors in other departments and actively volunteer for projects when they arise on the team. Join groups supported by the company and constantly get involved; every interaction is a chance to further promote yourself. I've had many co-workers go on to different teams and say it was a night and day experience. Regardless to if you switch teams or leave the company entirely, you'll come out of the experience having a greater sense of what you want out of an employer. Be patient with yourself, and remember your personal health and growth are most important. Generally speaking, United's community impact and values are amazing, and if you can focus on the larger picture rather than the dynamic of leadership on this particular team, the possibilities are endless.
cons:
Management is the biggest setback of this team, and as a result there's constant re-organization and turnover. General management rarely interacts with associates and is often unaware of daily issues/stress, and tends to avoid conflict. As a result assistant managers are poorly led and can also fail to deliver monthly reviews, support feedback, or maintain consistent and informed updates. Even with good intention, the lack of initiative, fairness or explanation leaves team feeling unsupported and reliant on senior teammates for guidance. The overall lack of transparency when it comes to evaluating performance, merit increases and promotions results in questioning of favoritism, bias and discrimination. 

This role transitioned from Corporate Communications to Contact Centers, and as a result came with some cultural changes. This job is directly centered in customer service, and while there are some appreciative interactions, you do deal with a brunt of anger and disappointed customers. You learn overtime to have a thick skin, however as a 24 hour operation this can be taxing and many have dealt with issues w/ mental health as a result. Your schedule is based on seniority, which could mean working overnights for a prolonged period. For this reason, there's an even greater need to feel supported, and have management present and available to care for the overall needs of each person.

You do not get to directly choose your base location from ALL of the United bases! When you are in training you will be given a list of bases with available flight attendant openings. We were given 6 choices of locations around the United States and asked to rank our preferences. Then when we received our base assignments our entire training group was sent to only 2 of the 6 bases. We were told we could transfer within 6 months. Although this is true... if the base you are wanting to work out of does not have openings you will not be able to go there until space becomes available. Some places have a transfer waiting list of 1,000+ people. All transfers are based on seniority. Also, Flight Attendant Pay does not change whether you are based out of SFO (higher cost of living) or Houston (lower cost of living). Flight Attendant hourly pay/hours worked need to begin when Flight Attendants are required to report for duty. Currently, Flight Attendant hourly pay/hours worked do not begin until the aircraft door is closed and they end when the aircraft door is re-opened. While a Flight Attendant is between flights, flights are delayed, or is awaiting a flight (in full uniform) we are paid a per diem rate of $1.25 per hour. When I asked management about this being illegal, I was told United operates under old Railroad Laws thus strategically gets away with not having to pay Flight Attendants their hourly rate/hours worked. Here's an example: report for duty time is 6:00am (FA's are expected to be prepared and dressed in uniform.) Customer Boarding time is 7:00am. (FA earns $1.25) Aircraft door closes at 8:00am (FA earns $2.50 for two hours of work) How is this ok?
